Here is how the dilemma is ended-

1. God by definition IS omnipotent, it is what we mean when we use the term “god.”

2. Because he is omnipotent he is the principle without principle and the source of every other principle, including morality.

3. Being the source of morality, what he decrees is objectively good.

4. Therefore, all his commands are good.

5. Now, because all his commands are good, he will not command that which contradicts what he has already commanded, because that would mean he is subject to change, which means he is acted upon by outside sources, making him imperfect and therefore not omnipotent.

6. The reconciliation of the goodness of the commands of God is the recognition that all his commands resolve themselves in a universal good.

7. For example, I tell my son it is wrong to deceive others. But then I tell him to lie about where he will be tomorrow at 5 pm to his mother. Seems hypocritical and inconsistent. Except that we are having a surprise party for his mother. Did I fail my son as a father in terms of moral consistency? Let us ask something analogous to God- If he is God and the source of Good and all his acts are good, then any contradiction we see is merely apparent and will resolve itself in a universal good.

Huh. The Euthryphro dilemma seems better suited to the Greek pantheon then the Christian God. In Christianity, God is considered omnibenevolent, but also omnipresent and omniscient. The hypothetical where God just changes his mind makes absolutely no sense in this context, as he's all knowing, all the time. If this is the case, the standard for goodness (being like God) is static. So while Socrates arguments was quite logical, he wasn't even talking about the same concept as the Christian God.
Also, while God is static, what things mean to a culture is not. If in one language a harmless word (say it means 'apple') is actually a slur in another language, its not like everyone who says apple in the first culture is sinning. It's not what you say (or how you dress) that makes it a sin, it's what it signifies. Gold chains, braids, tattoos, and the mixing of fabrics means something different in one culture then it does in another, and there is a whole field of research digging into the setting of Ancient Israel and Roman Palestine to understand what was meant by the commands. The meaning is then taken and reapplied to the modern context. If tattoos were associated with paganism at the time, what are symbols of modern idolatry that we shouldn't promote?
That doesn't make the divine command theory easy. Theodicies are still not enough for many people. I just feel the video misrepresented what the divine command theory really means and where the dilemma in it really is.

A dilemma is of the form A vs Not A. It is a false dilemma if it is of the form A vs B vs C. Euthyphro's dilemma is a false dilemma that can be resolved by seeing that God's nature IS the good. The good is not arbitrated by God bc he cannot defy his own nature (A), and the good doesn't exist outside of God (B). It also doesn't mean that it's impossible for God to do evil, it's just that He would not. No dilemma, no internal inconsistencies, Divine Command Theory still stands but at least we are all educated on the traditional attacks. Thanks Crash Course!

For those wondering some responses to this, I'm familiar with one response to the Euthyphro dilemma, one by William Lane Craig:


Craig's response in his book Reasonable Faith is to take the latter horn of the dilemma but argue that this does not lead to morality becoming unacceptably arbitrary. He argues this by saying that it is impossible for God to command us to do certain things in virtue of his nature, and "counterfactuals with impossible antecedents have no non-vacuous truth value." So basically, if you said "if God commanded baby torture, would that make it good?", Craig would say that it is impossible for God to command baby torture in virtue of his nature, so the counterfactual you are implying has no non-vacuous truth value.

You leave out a big area of Devine Command Theory – Covenants.  Also, not everything God commands is on the basis of morality.  This latter area would cover God's telling Abraham to sacrifice his only son (a test of obedience) and many of the Mosaic Covenant laws which served to make Israel a unique or holy people.  On the first category, Christians are aware of the Mosaic Covenant laws but respond, that is not my covenant.  Christians see themselves under the New Covenant or New Testament which God had promised in Jeremiah 31.  So the moral laws of the Old Testament continue because they are rooted in the character of God, but the ceremonial laws for national Israel do not.  Also, the Euthyphro dilemma is a false dilemma for Christians and Jews – God's laws are seen to be rooted in his nature because he is good and holy.  So both questions are true – He commands them because they are true and they are true because he commands them.

the three issues introduced at the beginning of the video, while, at first glance and out of context can seem confusing, really are all things that make sense when read into.


The ancient israelites made a covenant with God, before the coming of Christ. In this covenant were hundreds of rules for man, and hundreds of promises by God. The rules included the practical, or "humans dealing with humans" such as washing your hands before you eat, and not eating rotten meat. Also there was moral and social practicality, like don't kill and don't steal, take care of widows, etc.. These helped keep a peaceful society. Then there were rules that were meant to distinguish the israelites from the pagan countries, rules such as dress codes and circumcision, symbolic things which identified the Israelites as God's people.


The second kind of rules were rules on how to approach or worship God. Very specific, symbolic instructions on building a tabernacle and ceremonies.


All of these rules were assigned a purpose, their purpose was as a mirror. Time and time again the new testament asks "can the law save you?" or says "if you keep the whole law, but fail in one way, you are guilty of it all." The purpose of the law was to put humans in their place. Pagans and the tower of babel were examples of people trying to reach God, instead of having faith in Him to reach them. The law, which no one could follow, highlighted the need for a saviour.
Enter: Jesus.


The old Israelite commandments are not binding to anyone other than the ancient people group that entered a covenant. Jesus eliminated the need for human sacrificial atonement because Jesus came as the intercessor for us all, the intermediary between us and God. All of us are "sheep lead astray" and Jesus "bore the transgressions (wrongdoings) of us all" as an eternal atonement (appeasement)


As for the reason that modern Christians still follow the 10 commandments, we don't, not all of them, it just so happens that 9/10 of them were repeated in the new testament. Jesus came to fulfil the law. Jesus also kind of exploded the idea of the Sabbath, and most Christians do not hold a holy sabbath (saturday). When asked what the greatest commandment was, Jesus responded with the first commandment, more or less, by saying "Love God with all your heart, soul and strength." and then he gave a second, "love your neighbor as yourself" We learned much of the symbolic meaning of the law in the new testament. For instance with murder, "you say do not kill, but I tell you that any man who has hatred has commited murder in his heart." or with adultrey "any man that looks at a woman with lust commits adultery in his heart." learning to follow the spirit of the law above the letter.


As for the new testament laws he gave, wearing gold chains was a sign of vanity, and vanity isn't good if you back up in the timothy passage, it starts by saying that people should be modest, and then gives examples how.. and you shouldn't gossip.


Anyways, my point is that there are still people, myself included, that truly do believe that the entire Bible is literal and true, moral and practical. I try very hard to live by it, and I do not dress funky or do anything religious. The entire misconception is this: People believe that for God to love them they have to do stuff to appease Him. The whole message of the Bible is that there is nothing that you can do to work your way to heaven. "For it is by Grace (undeserved favor, mercy) that you are saved, through Faith, and not of works...) -Ephesians.

You therefore don't have to refute either horn in order to remain rationally consistent with divine command theory. There's an alternative... God's commands right actions because He is good. God's own nature is the standard of "goodness" and morality. Divine commandments are expressions of God's inherent nature.

It is worrying, perilous even, that most people in the world still hold on to the divine command theory of morality.

Morality and religion should be separated. Morality should be based on reason, not religion.

A morality based on religion leads to some nonsensical results (as the video explains): either (1) the word "good" loses its meaning; it has its meaning reduced to just "godlike"; but this cannot be true because we know empirically as a fact that the concept of "good" exists independently from the concept of "God" (for example, there was already a Chinese word for "good" before the advent of Christianity or Islam in China), or (2) God isn't omnipotent because there is at least one thing -- goodness -- that doesn't originate from God; worse, there is something outside of God that binds God and his actions -- there is some standard of goodness that God has to obey; next, the Bible and the Quran would then become unnecessary. But all these wouldn't sit comfortably with a theist. So if someone tries to expound morality using religious justifications, it only means he doesn't know what he is talking about.

But most importantly, separating morality and religion means there would be one less reason for killing, war and genocide.

Many of the OT rules are what Catholics call "discipline not doctrine."  In other words, there were good reasons for them, but they weren't inherently good or bad.  It's kind of like if your parents tell you that you have to go to bed at 9pm because you have school in the morning.  There is nothing inherently good or bad about going to bed at that specific time, but there is a good reason for the rule.  As circumstances change, your parents may also change the rule.  A common interpretation for why the Israelites had to follow so many seemingly arbitrary rules is because God was trying to keep them separate from the numerous pagan societies because every time so mixed with those societies  they started worshipping idols.  There is also a distinction between the "old" and "new" covenants.  The rules in Leviticus applied only under the old covenant (e.g. before  Christ's death and resurrection).  Under the new covenant, they no longer apply.  As for the NT prohibition against women wearing braids, I believe this was because female braids likely symbolized something bad in the culture of the time.

"God is totally unconstrained by his environment. God is limited (we might say) only by his character. God, being good, cannot lie, be deceived, act with evil intent...he is free to do as he wills, and his character (Who He Is) controls his will." -J. W. Sire (The Universe Next Door, p. 33-34)

The argument that the God of the Bible, if he so pleased, could flip the absolutes of moral law is invalid. He can only act according to his character. From his character stem the absolutes of moral law claimed in the Bible. To reverse these absolutes would be to contradict his own character, which is impossible because God is limited by his character and will only will that which is consistent with his character.

The Bible lays out the ten commandments as the foundation of morality. The others Hank mentioned were moment-specific. For example, Paul told Timothy women shouldn't wear braids, because in the city where Timothy was evangelizing, pagan women would wear excessive jewelry and hairstyles to honor pagan gods. In this case, this was seen as a stumbling block to Christians who had converted from paganism, much like you wouldn't drink around a recovering alcoholic. Outside this specific church's pagan roots, the command doesn't apply.

Therefore, though I don't agree with it completely, I tend to think horn one is the least problematic. It rejects the concept of "good" entirely, which is a problematic concept anyway as it is not consistent across human society or the animal kingdom, and instead focuses on whether you obey or disobey the creator. It's essentially a moral antirealist stance.

I would like to point something out. There are two parts to the Bible: The Old and the New Testament. The Old Testament was written mainly for the Jews, though Christians do reference it and follow it as inspired by God, and the New Testament was written for Christians, which was for Jews and Gentiles alike. The Ten Commandments, found in the Old Testament, are all restated in various forms in the New Testament as well, and so are continued to be commanded, whereas several of the other commandments found elsewhere, such as the linen and wool, and not restated in the New Testament and are therefore no longer binding. When Jesus said that the greatest commandments are these, that we should love the Lord our God with all our hearts, soul, mind, and strength, He was merely restating the first four commandments, which relate to man's relationship with God. When He said the second greatest commandment was to love our neighbor as ourselves, He was restating the last six commandments, which relate to man's relationship to other men. Besides that, there are several instances where the commandments, except the Sabbath day, but that is still debated, are explicitly re-commanded, such as adultery and murder, by Jesus in His sermon on the mount.

So the Euthyphro dilemma is the following: (i) morally good acts are willed by God because they are morally good, or (ii) morally good acts are morally good because they are willed by God. If (i) is true, then God is redundant. If (ii) is true, then 'goodness' is arbitrary.

William Lane's Craig's riposte to the Euthyphro dilemma is that God is good because this is a necessary part of his being (ontological argument), and therefore what he commands is good as a result. Thank you Mr. Green for presenting these introductions and arguments. I'd like to briefly address a couple of the points made.

1. "In a sense, that's what the Bible is FOR........a divine rule book, a sort of owners manual for human morality."
I understand why many people, including Christians, presume that this is what the Bible is "for". While the moral law IS part of the Bible however, there is much much more to it than that, and any attempt to reduce the Bible to law and then argue against it is disingenuous at best.

2. It seemed like you were using the examples at the beginning as if you believed that EVERY command made by God in the Bible was to be taken as a universally binding decree, which it is not. Some of them were given to particular people, others for a specific time, etc. Many commands were ceremonial, and most importantly, some decrees were bound to a specific covenant with a specific purpose. One of the major paradigms of the New Testament was to reveal just what many of those laws, ceremonies, and sacrifices were designed for and WHO they were pointing to and ultimately fulfilled by (namely Jesus). Once they were fulfilled, they were no longer needed, much like a scaffolding on a tall building.

2. Euthyphro: Here is a quote from the Holman QuickSource Guide to Christian Apologetics by Doug Powell that I believe addresses the dilemma. Consider below:

"There is a third possibility that answers both objections and shows moral objectivism to be completely coherent. This explanation says that goodness is a reflection of God's character. Goodness is not external to God, nor is it something that has authority over God. Rather, that which corresponds to His character is called good. His preferences are extensions of His character, not an arbitrary decision on His part. Because His character does not change, morality is grounded in the very character of God."

The correct response to the Euthyphro Dilemma is to point out that God just is goodness. God's nature is goodness itself, as it is love itself. To say that God commands that we do good is just to say that goodness demands it. Thus, there is neither anything sovereign over God (such as an God-independent standard of goodness) nor is there anything arbitrary about about God's commands making something good.

I have trouble seeing what is wrong with the second horn of the dilemma, but it does utterly demand that you also find a second metaethic that explains what is good.

God is good. God is also omnipotent. God can, therefore, choose to command all manner of terrible things, but it is not in His nature to do so; we can therefore discern that something has gone wrong (either with our perceptions or with the purported God being otherwise) if we perceive apparent commands that are blatantly immoral. However, God might be supposed to have superior moral reasoning skills to our own, and so a command we wouldn't have expected might nonetheless be correct for reasons external to God, who commanded it because of its goodness. This makes "listen to God" a far better guide to the good than one's own merely human ability to reason morally, but only once one has observed the apparently-perfect goodness of God in the first place.

The fact that God is unable to redefine the good is no more a problem for divine omnipotence than his inability to make a circle with corners - few thinkers attribute to God the ability to do the logically impossible, and morals are as fundamental as the laws of mathematics.

(I do not believe this, because I don't believe in an omnipotent God, but it's a self-consistent position.)

The Eutyphro dilemma is a false dilemma, for there is still one third option.

Short version:
God commands something good because He is good.

Long version:
This argument is not based on the Bible, yet it's an argument in favor of the divine command theory. If objective morality exists (as our conscience naturally reveals to all of us), that means there is a moral code whose existence trascends time, space, matter and the human mind, yet you require a mind to grasp it. It sounds unlikely to me that such code just exists and that's it; rather, I think such a conceptual entity exists due to the existence of a timeless, spaceless, immaterial mind, who is intrinscially moral and therefore personal. Due to its goodness and timelessness, this mind cannot change objective morality.

Does that mean this being is not all-powerful? Although this argument doesn't tell us whether or not that's the case, omnipotence is the property of having all the skills, being able to do anything; therefore, an all-powerful being cannot do logical absurds (such as married bachelors or squared circles, or an invisible yet pink unicorn) because those are not things, they're words put together that have no meaning.

Jesus's "do unto others" is hardly different from Kant's formulation of universality, and in fact you will find Kant supposed the morality of religion could be rediscovered through pure reason. Regardless, I think it's great that an organization like Crash Course is encouraging people to seriously consider this kind of thing! Commands in the Old Testament were only applicable to the Jews before Christ came. Commands in the New Testament are still binding, but the audience and the cultural climate of the audience must be taken into consideration when discussing the need to follow such commands. For example, braids in the time of place of 1 Timothy were considered excessive adornment and trying to look "upper-class." Trying to make yourself more attractive to members of the opposite sex and trying to deceive people into thinking you are something other than what you are are the real problems, not necessarily the braids themselves. As such, in the letter from Paul, the braid command only applies to societies where braids have those cultural implications.

Just a note: The Ten Commandments are not binding. They were metaphorically nailed to the cross with the Old Law when Jesus died. Most of them, however, are completely necessary when Jesus gave the commands: "Love God" and "love thy neighbor"

What you've pointed out is 100% true, and is a very big problem for the DCT, ASSUMING that this is all there is to the theory. However, there is actually a little more to the discussion, because there are two very different versions of the DCT. The first, also known as Theological Voluntarism, revolves around the WILL of God. An action is right or wrong because God commands or forbids it; in other words, moral value is determined by the brute force of God's willing it so. It's like the old parental retort about why the child should clean his room or wear matching socks, "Because I said so, that's why". And yes, this makes morality 100% arbitrary, and easily demolished by the Euthyphro Dilemma. It is also logically self-defeating and unhelpful in way of a "decision procedure". This understanding is the basis on which many criticize religion as being blind adherence to arbitrary rules.
But, there is another option.
The second version of the DCT places moral value not in God's brute "say so", or in a standard outside himself, but in his very NATURE. Actions are right or wrong only if they conform to God's character. Furthermore, the "rules" or commandments are understood to describe God's character, as applied to particular circumstances. Because divine commands are the practical application of divine character, they are not arbitrary. And yet, the nature they describe is inherent to God himself, so they do not appeal to an outside standard which He is "recommending". The rules provide insight into the overarching Nature behind them; to more general principles which are helpful to interpret specifics that appear contradictory, or vague. For example, this is why many within the christian faith community do not adhere to all of the regulations in the Pentateuch. They see the Laws as falling into three categories: Moral (such as the 10 Commandments), Ceremonial (such as circumcision, animal sacrifice, ritual bathing, etc), and Civil (such as building a rail around one's roof -- flat roofs were used for extra living space, and could be a safety hazard; or not eating shrimp -- they were often not cooked properly in Ancient Cultures, and carried dangerous bacteria). The Moral laws tell us about God's nature, and so are still applicable; the ones detailing building codes and FDA style health warnings do not, and are now culturally irrelevant. The idea is understanding and obeying the "spirit" of the law, not just the "letter".
The difference here is subtle, but very important. Version 1 is crushed by the Euthyphro Dilemma, while Version 2 is not. Version 1 can seem to produce conflicting moral duties, and is unhelpful regarding actions not specifically mentioned. Version 2 works off the idea that the prescribed rules describe God's nature, and so offer a procedure for "grey" areas and conflicts.

In regards to the Euthyphro Problem I believe the 2 questions are indeed two ways of asking the same thing. The question attempts to prove that the reason or cause of God's commands must exist outside of God but the key to answer is to understand the nature of God.

So the answer to Euthyphro's first question is yes because "God's commands" permits and enables "right actions" which results in harmonious existence with God which by definition is "good".

The answer to Euthyphro's second question is yes because "right actions" result in "good" in that they permit harmonious existence with God and harmonious existence with God require "God's commandments".

This is made clear when you break down the meaning of these 4 ideas.

Firstly, God is NOT the supreme being WITHIN existence but is the ESSENCE of existence.

Secondly, "good" is anything that is in harmony (consistent) with God's intentions/will and since God is the essence of reality all things consistent with God's will do indeed exist. Thus "good" is same as "existence" or "that which continually exists". Evil is the absense of good which is to say that evil is non-existence or "anything" transitioning into non-existenence (ie, decaying, diminishing, dying).

Thirdly, a command from God not only grants the permission/authorization to perform the command but also the ABILITY to perform it. This is because God is in perfect harmony with Himself and thus He would not (1) will/intend for something to be and then (2) permit/authorize for that something to be but then (3) NOT enable/empower that something to be since this would be a contradiction on God's part. So when God commands us to do something he authorizes and empowers us to fulfill that command.

Fourthly a "right action" is simply a "good action" which is an action that permits harmonious existence with God and thus continued existence period. So when "God commands" He permits and enables "right action" which results in continued, harmonious existence with God which, by definition, is "good".

So again, the answer to Euthyphro's first question is yes because "God's commands" permits and enables "right actions" which results in harmonious existence with God which by definition is "good".

Speaking as a christian who believes in the divine command theory, I would like to respond. The first thing that I need to clarify is that I hold that first horn, in a sense. I believe that what is good originates in God's nature which is unchanging, but is revealed through His words, actions and creation. This does mean that there are things that God cannot do, for instance the bible says that God cannot lie (Titus 1:2). In this belief, God's nature is unchanging and He is the perfect source of moral revelation, though that includes what He has revealed in creation through what He has made, not just revelation from the Bible alone. This does mean that if God came down with new commands that those new commands would be binding, but it also means that those new commands would not contradict the spirit of what He said previously. In fact, this is exactly what we believe happened with the New Testament. God had one covenant (on contract if you will) with his followers in the Old Testament. A part of that contract included a note that it would one day change. The work of Jesus Christ constituted God's work in bringing that promised new contract (for reasons outlined most clearly in the letter to the Hebrews). This brought about a change in the commands that needed to be followed, not because God changed, but because the nature of our relationship with God changed.
This leads to the challenge that you presented on how we know which commands have changed and which remain unchanged. First the new testament says that the ceremonial laws are gone, because they were only there to symbolize and help God's followers look forward to (or to meditate on) things that became realities in the new covenant. That is a mouth full and it is explained Paul's in the letter to the Hebrews (a book of the Bible that is very much about the change of covenants).
Second, the old covenant (or contract) with God's followers had them acting as a theocratic nation, and it came complete with a legal system. The new contract calls for God's followers to obey God while living in other nations and generally following their laws (except for when those laws contradict the contract that we have with God and the things that He commands that we do). This means that all the national law stuff is out.
In addition to those two points, it should also be noted that some of the laws are simply specific applications of unchanging principals. For example, the law that forbids wearing clothes made from wool and linen is a specific example of the command not to participate in other religions. In the time when that command was given, fertility religions were common and people believed that spring came because the gods had sex. They wanted the gods to have sex early and often and attempted to convince them to do so in interesting ways, mostly by mixing things that weren't supposed to mix. For example they would plant alternating vegetables, make their clothes out of alternating wool and linen and several other things that lead to seemingly weird commands in Leviticus and Deuteronomy. These were common practices. Like reading a horoscope, they were so common that people were not likely to think anything about them, and like reading a horoscope they violated the command against participating in other religions so these specific examples were given to make it clear that even these common things were not allowed. Many people in the old testament still worshiped Baal and ashtoreth, thus participating in one of these very fertility religions.
The tattoos for the dead is another reference to a religious practice, not a rule against modern decorative tattoos (whatever you may think of the modern practice). Modesty looks different in different cultures. Gossip is just generally bad. Knowing that some commands only make sense in their historical context means that when you read the Bible you must consider not only which covenant you are reading about, but also the context in which the statement was made. Very often the Bible will present an unchanging principal and then give specific cultural application. Understanding this means reading books of the Bible as a whole, not in individual pieces. (BTW we added the chapter and verse headings, and we divided some books into two books when they originally were one.) It also means looking for consistent principals and thinking deeply about God's nature, His commands and our relationship and contract with Him.
Fortunately, in america today it is easy to get solid Bible commentaries that explain things related to historical context which does make it easier to understand some of the verses that just are confusing without that context. Also it is helpful to look for reason statements. To give an example of this, many racist point out that in the old testament there are verses prohibiting Jews from marrying gentiles. They then say that God opposes interracial marriage. However, with even the slightest attention to context you will notice that 1. the reason given is that God does not want his followers marring into other religions 2. there are explicate instructions for marrying people from other ethnic backgrounds as long as they convert first, and 3. that God backed Moses' marriage to a Ethiopian (Cushite) woman (a black woman actually) when this caused outrage from Aaron and Miriam. It also includes other stories of interracial marriage that it approves of where the couple followed God alone (The very short book of Ruth is one such example). The New Testament maintains this command that Christians not marry people who are not Christians. The idea that if you are a follower of God that you must not marry someone who does not share your faith is the principle that remains the same because, as the Bible points out, the God of the Bible is a jealous God. It is because God is a jealous God that this is wrong, and that is also the Biblical reason that in marriage (which the Bible says that God created) adultery is wrong. God's creation was designed to reflect His nature and perverting what God made is sin.

When Abraham was about to kill his son God said "Do not lay a hand on the boy, Do not do anything to him. Now I know that you fear God, because you have not withheld from me your son, your only son." God was not enticing Abraham to do wrong, but was testing him to see if he would do what was right and his faith in God.
God was not instituting or condoning child sacrifice. As seen in Deuteronomy 12:31 and the other passages above, God abhors child sacrifice. It's important to remember that God prevented the sacrifice from actually occurring. He did not desire the sacrifice as an act of worship or for any other reason beyond testing Abraham.
God was not telling Abraham to do wrong.God has the right to take human life and could therefore authorize Abraham to do so in a particular case. Note that had Abraham decided of his own accord to sacrifice Isaac, he would have been wrong and his act would have been condemned by God (as were other human-initiated sacrifices).

I understand it's difficult to properly address a millennia old problem in just seven or eight minutes, but to reject divine command theory because God's commands are arbitrary demands a simplistic view of God and his message to humanity.

Here are some things to consider:
-The video suggests that God's ability to change his commands is what makes them arbitrary. This is problematic because it assumes that A) God would want to change his mind, B) God is subject to time and is changing (in the way we understand change) at all, and C) that God changing his commands wouldn't have far reaching changes on reality, including what we perceive as good.
-The video goes to great lengths to separate God and goodness. As a proponent of divine command theory, I reject this idea. Goodness is a subset of God. If God changes, then goodness changes. If we see something in God's commandments that strikes us as not good, then the problem is not with God but with our interpretation of the commandments and/or our understanding of goodness.
-The video suggests that a cursory glance at scripture is all it takes to understand God's commands. I think this is a huge mistake. Plenty of my interlocutors in the comments have suggested that context is important, and I think this where the video misses the point - and by that I don't mean that you should read the whole chapter or the whole book or the entire bible to properly understand context. You have to include much more than that. You have to consider the room you're reading it in, the time of day, the age you are when you read it, the mood you are in when you read it, and the motivation you had for reading it in the first place. Any representation of divine command theory that suggests that scripture is not a living document is a straw man.

Anyone with a desire to anchor their moral system to Divine Will takes on a much greater responsibility than simply memorizing a few verses of scripture. It takes a lifetime of study and prayer and worship and love to even begin to know the nature of goodness, let alone the nature of God. Faith comes in when you believe that this pursuit will allow you to make the most enlightened decision when a moral quandary presents itself.

I think this video did not touch on the Christian God with a great deal of specificity, so I will. If God's word is itself moral, than that is fine for theists. However, as stated in Numbers 23:19, Malachi 3:6, Hebrews 13:8 and so on, God is unchanging. Therefore, his word and universal morality are equally the same as they cannot change. So the first issue is not an issue but more an issue of semantics.

On the other argument, if God can only command right action because he himself is moral, then why does God do immoral things (e.g. command killing of infants, play favorites with the Jews, etc.). Typical Christian arguments about sin have defined sin as detachment from God because God is moral/good. But if God has acted against his commandments, has God sinned? If so, he is not the authority on morality. If not, than he is not an unchanging God and the Bible contains lies. Plus, the argument that God had to do these things in the Old Testament in order to save his people in order to bring about the coming of Jesus falls flat as he is an unchanging God. If he has ever been immoral, he is therefore always immoral.

To be fair to DCT, I don't think you were charitable enough to the horns of the dilemma.

Morality being arbitrarily determined by God really isn't much of a problem. It still satisfies everything that we look for in establishing a moral code. The only problem with it is that feels intuitively wrong. This really ought to have been said in the video, because this is a really important point, and honestly those who accept DCT usually pick this horn especially in ancient history. Most people in ancient history had absolutely no problem being subservient to a superior, and we're taking a bit of our modern individualism and injecting that into a historical problem with historical context.

There isn't a logical inconsistency at all with accepting that horn.

With respect to the second horn, strictly speaking you're right. If the statement is taken absolutely then it is logically inconsistent with God's (gods') omnipotence, but that's assuming a naive understanding of "freedom." Which is also historically relevant. Not until around the time of John Lock and the modern empiricists was freedom understood as the ability to have done otherwise. Before, freedom was understood much more losely and the circumstances weren't really an inhibition to your freedom as the illogical is nonexistent in reality so it wouldn't really make sense to be "free" to be illogical (in fact, you can make a pretty good argument as Plato, Aristotle, and Socrates all did that illogical "decisions" aren't "free choices" at all).

In either case, the second horn is a bit more nuanced and understandable why you wouldn't go into that kind of depth in a 10 min video about DCT, but the point that arbitrary morality isn't actually a real problem for DCT (other than our "feelings" and "intuitions") ought to have been mentioned.

Maimonides discusses divine command theory and (IIRC) provides the following conclusion: the concepts of "good and evil" are subjective judgments made by mankind as an attempt to categorize the world in which we live - the split between the personal conceptions of "good and evil" (which are products of the imagination) and right/just and wrong/unjust (whether an action is conducive to the purpose of creation) is exactly what Edenic sin of eating from the "tree of knowledge of GOOD AND EVIL" illustrates. The "snake's" argument is that the capacity to create a personal system of morality ("knowing" good and evil) is itself a "divine" ability.

Thus God himself doesn't define "good and evil," since he is above those concepts.

God DOES define "right and wrong" since the evaluation of those are contingent upon the purpose of God's creation, of which God is the ultimate arbiter.

This also explains why there are instances where an individual is told to transgress what is otherwise established divine law - in the specific instances faced by that individual, the "base" law would not lead to results conducive to the purpose of creation.

Divine Command Theory is not synonymous with the belief that all morality derives from God, and it is not the traditional Christian view. Prior to the late Middle Ages, most Christian philosophers east and west rejected the voluntarism of DCT, and based their ethics largely on the Christian-Platonic conception of the Good. Rejection of DCT is somewhat less common in most streams of Judaism and Islam, as I understand, but critiques within those traditions have certainly been made.

Religion has filled this role for thousands of years, but now that religion is loosing that role we need to develops secular cultural standards to replace it.   There are two down sides to this approach.  First we need to build our own moral framework, which we have done in the past and called religion, so it can be done again. It's only as strong as our willingness as a group to follow it.

The second horn of Euthephro doesn't actually pose new problems.

The first complaint, that God is not omnipotent is only true if you define omnipotence in a fashion designed to cause contradiction. Mathematics, apart from those aspects of geometry that depend on the curvature of space, is entirely independent of creation. God cannot make the square root of two rational because when you unpack the meaning of the statement it is complete nonsense. Being unable to make evil good or good evil does not add to this "problem" already presented by the existence of self-consistent logical structures.

The second complaint, that Man should ignore God and go to the source presumes that the source is accessible to Man. When this series gets to utilitarianism, for example, I'm sure the presenter will cover the problem that naive utilitarianism requires omniscience and unlimited predictive capacity. These are things that at least the common monotheistic interpretations of God have that humans lack.

Hm . . . John Milton (along with other pre-modernist and early modernist English Christians) believed that Jesus' sacrifice did actually make the Old Testament commandments moot. Once Jesus "wiped the slate" of humanity's sin, humans all basically became responsible for themselves and for trying to decide what is right and wrong on our own. Milton wrote that individuals have the responsibility to practice the hard liberty of choosing and believing for ourselves. According to Milton, there are objectively "good" and "bad" decisions, but we can't always know what decisions are truly "good" or "bad." We just have to be as informed as possible and then do our best to be "good," and that's basically the only way to develop good morals (a lifelong process) and salvation.

What a simpleton philosopher!  If God created the universe, than he must be above and outside it. God being above and outside the universe means that he can create moral law and contain it within natural law, and he can declare moral law. Because he is outside of the universe, the laws of the universe only apply to the universe that we know, and he can act fully within moral law within the universe, without being bound by moral law outside of the uninverse.  Since we are bound by the universe, what God does outside of our universe is has no consequence on us and cannot be known by us, thus the question is mute. God being God has complete freedom to limit himself the the morality of this universe, without loosing any of his omnipotence. But remember that when God chooses to do a miracle in the universe, he is showing that he is above his natural laws, even though he chooses to not break his moral law.  Perhaps, a better question would be, "If God does a miracle in this world, is he breaking either the natural law or moral law?"  A wise person could argue at least the four sides of this question.

There is a way to make the first postulate work: God COULD rewrite the rules of morality should he want to; however, that would not spare humanity from the logistical cause and effect that would ensue. For example, God COULD make murder moral and righteous, but doing so would quickly result in the human race driving itself to extinction with the possible exception of a few "heretics". One might think of a computer programmer designing a language: Sure, they COULD make the "AND" and "OR" operations swap functions, but, why would they? It would be counterproductive to the overall design and needlessly confuse people. As for the stranger commands that people reject, personally I feel anything farther than the Ten Commandments is mostly relevant only to the time period (you can't deny the kosher diet was a pretty nifty cheat sheet for those lacking advanced cooking techniques), or else can be distorted by human interpretation.

Besides, regardless of what God declares to be moral, humans will continue to act immorally whether or not they intentionally mean to do so. That's just human nature.

Where Did God Come From? A newborn child, cold and hungry, cries out to the universe for food and warmth. He is gathered up in his mother’s arms, and is comforted, and fed.
We don’t remember this experience, but it is one we’ve all shared. I believe it leaves us with a sense that we might implore a greater being to come to our aid in time of trouble, and that it is likely the seed of the idea of ‘God’.
On a cold day, I walked out of the apartment ready to shiver. Stepping out of the shadow and into the sunlight, I felt a warmth and comfort, as if I were loved by the Sun. And I understood how easy it was for our ancestors to view the Sun as a god.
In early history people worshipped multiple gods, prayed to them for favors and offered them gifts so that the rains would water their crops, and the river would not flood their homes. By coincidence, this sometimes appeared to work. Psychologists have since discovered that behavior that was intermittently rewarded was more difficult to extinguish than behavior that was consistently rewarded. And so superstition flourished.
But then something new was added. Monotheism took the strong position that there was only one God.
And not only was this the God to pray to and worship, but this God also expected you to follow rules. If you followed the commandments, you would prosper, if not in this life, then in the next.
I remember the preachers from my youth, Oral Roberts and Norman Vincent Peale, teaching that God is a Good God, and that following Him brings both blessings and expectations. I remember the prayer at dinner, "God is Great, God is Good …".
God became a way to make being good and doing good both valuable and sacred. And that is why the idea is still useful today, even by those of us who use the term in a literary rather than a literal sense.

The idea that God would be bound by morality isn't necessarily a restriction of His omnipotence. God, as many philosphers define Him, is infinitely good as well as infinitely capable. Saying that because He only does good things that means He's not omnipotent is like saying He's not omnipotent because he can't change what "creating something" means. The fact that he can act immorally but doesn't ADDS to his omnibenevolence, just as the fact that He can be ignorant of something but isn't adds to his omniscience.

The main problem of the horn is the grounding problem - it's clearly not God that dictates what is moral. The problem isn't that God is not omnipotent.

The sequence is that the consequentialists must first figure out which rules produce the best results for everyone. Next the deontologists forget the reasons, rhetorically replacing them with God or Nature to spread the rules. Gentle suggestion (disclaimer: I'm an atheist). Maybe the second horn isn't so bad, God commands X because X is good. This sounds bad because it means something outside of God determines the rightness or goodness of X, but perhaps that isn't such a bad thing. The two objections in the video I reply to below:

Objection (1) it means God is not omnipotent, as there are values and moral rules that God doesn't create and can't change.
Reply: Usually, God's omnipotence is considered to mean that God can do anything that is metaphysically possible, like creating this universe, determining some physical constants, causing a thunderstorm to kill someone, curing an illness etc. A being that can control the entirely of the physical world is omnipotent, at least on a reasonable definition. The fact that SOME things can't be done, not even by God, is a tangential point. Consider some examples of things that even a die-hard theist may admit God can't do:
-- that God can't draw a 4-sided triangle, or prove that 3+4 = 10 [cuz logic],
-- nor can God do evil [against his own nature],
-- nor can God have-not-have made me [he could destroy me, or perhaps rewrite me out of history -- but still at least God would remember having made me before, so I did exist in his eternal timeline]
-- nor can God create a rock too heavy for him to lift [because it would be a rock so heavy that an infinitely strong being can't lift it, which is a self-contradictory, nonsensical concept]
These are debatable but MOST people (except e.g. Rene Descartes) would agree with my first example, that God can't break the laws of logic or maths. So at least the idea of God not being able to do something is not that big a deal.
Coming to moral laws, maybe we could say that even though God can't create or change moral laws, that's not so bad after all: perhaps the moral laws are really a kind of logic, deducible like maths [this is Kant's belief about morality for example].
And if morality is just a corollary of logic, then the fact that God can't change it is no more an problem than the fact that God can't draw a 4-sided triangle,.

Objection (2) it means we don't need God, he is a pointless middleman and we could just go straight to morality (e.g. by working it out ourselves).
Reply: That doesn't follow. God is smarter, wiser and has more experience than us (e.g. by observing the history of this and other possible universes). As such, God may just be in a far better position to know about morality than we are. For example, people can deduce maths for themselves, but that DOESN'T mean that maths teachers are just pointless middlemen for learning about maths.


For me, the main objection to Divine Command theory - hinted at in the flash philosophy - is that it is impossible for humans to know that God DOES command X in the first place. I can read the Bible, or Quran, or listen to the Pope or some random vicar. Or I can have a vision under drugs, tiredness or desperation. Or I can pray and feel God's word. These are all potentially valid ways to learn God's word: BUT, how do I chose between them, especially when these sources of information may give conflicting instructions?

Even if I had the God-guy in the video visit me tonight, with lightning and a booming, glorious voice, telling me to do X, how do I know I'm not just hallucinating? God MIGHT have told Abraham to kill his only son, but then again perhaps Abraham should have thought "maybe I'm just hallucinating". The point is EVEN IF God exists and tries to talk to us, we have no way of knowing it.

It strikes me, that it is problematic to mention the euthyphro dilemma and not say anything about the theistic rejection of the dilemma. Theist Philosophers, Command Theorists, and other theists alike reject the dilemma by answering that God's nature, rather than his will or an external source ground goodness. By showing God is the good, rather than its maker, as a Platonic Demiurge would be, their is no arbitrary problem with goodness, nor is it co-eternal or an external constraint. The question of what the bible commands is more complex, as theists who hold it as the only objective standard of goodness also claim it is made by multiple authors, across long periods of time, and contains many genres of writing. The short answer many command theorists would give is that the Bible outlines the rules for understanding which commands are for us. This still leaves us, on the strength of the arguments given by those who disagree, to determine what commands bind us. Thst said, the condition is a bit different than the video claims.
